    AI isÂ intelligenceÂ exhibited byÂ machines, rather than humans or other animals (natural intelligence,Â NI).

    AI is a big concept, ML is just one subarea of AI. DL is just a part of ML, which uses DNN mapping function.

    List six subareas of AI:
    Knowledge Data science, Reasoning, Statistics, Nature Language Process (NLP), Planning, Computer Vision (CV), Neuroscience, Machine Learning (ML), Robotics and so on.

    MLÂ¶

    Machine learning ã€‚is the field of study that gives computers the ability to learn without being explicitly programmed.â€ â€” Arthur Samuel (1959)
    â€œA computer program is said to learn from experience E with respect to some class of tasks T and performance measure P, if its performance at tasks in T, as measured by P, improves with experience E.â€ â€” Tom Mitchell (1998)

    åˆ†ç±»Â¶

    Supervised learning ã€‚learning xâ‡’P(yâˆ£x)yx \xRightarrow{P(y|x)} yxP(yâˆ£x)â€‹y with labelsï½œtargets.

    ç”Ÿæˆæ¨¡å‹ & åˆ¤åˆ«æ¨¡å‹ âˆˆ\inâˆˆ Supervised learning

    • ç”Ÿæˆæ¨¡å‹ å­¦ä¹ å¾—åˆ° è”åˆæ¦‚ç‡åˆ†å¸ƒ P(x,y)P(x,y)P(x,y) ç„¶åæ±‚æ¡ä»¶æ¦‚ç‡åˆ†å¸ƒã€‚ä»¥ ç»Ÿè®¡å­¦ & bayes ä¸ºç†è®ºåŸºç¡€ã€‚

      æœ´ç´ è´å¶æ–¯ï¼Œæ··åˆé«˜æ–¯æ¨¡å‹ï¼Œéšé©¬å°”å¯å¤«æ¨¡å‹

    • åˆ¤åˆ«æ¨¡å‹ å­¦ä¹ å¾—åˆ° æ¡ä»¶æ¦‚ç‡åˆ†å¸ƒ P(yâˆ£x)P(y|x)P(yâˆ£x)

      SVMï¼Œå†³ç­–æ ‘ã€‚LRï¼Œã€‚

    Unsupervised learning ã€‚learning P(x)P(x)P(x) without labels.

    ç›‘ç£å­¦ä¹  & æ— ç›‘ç£å­¦ä¹  ç•Œé™æ˜¯æ¨¡ç³Šçš„ã€‚

    å› ä¸ºæ²¡æœ‰å®¢è§‚çš„åˆ¤æ–­æ¥åŒºåˆ†ç›‘ç£è€…æä¾›çš„å€¼ æ˜¯ featureï½œtargetã€‚é€šä¿—åœ°è¯´ï¼Œæ— ç›‘ç£å­¦ä¹ çš„å¤§å¤šæ•°å°è¯•æ˜¯æŒ‡ä»ä¸éœ€è¦äººä¸ºæ³¨é‡Šçš„æ ·æœ¬çš„åˆ†å¸ƒä¸­æŠ½å–ä¿¡æ¯ã€‚

    p(x)=âˆi=1np(xiâˆ£x1,â€¦,xiâˆ’1)p(x)=\prod\limits_{i=1}^np(x_i|x_1,\dots,x_{i-1})p(x)=i=1âˆnâ€‹p(xiâ€‹âˆ£x1â€‹,â€¦,xiâˆ’1â€‹) æ— ç›‘ç£å­¦ä¹  p(x)p(x)p(x) å¯è¢«åˆ†è§£æˆ n ä¸ªç›‘ç£å­¦ä¹ é—®é¢˜ã€‚

    Semi-supervised learning åŠç›‘ç£å­¦ä¹  ã€‚ä¸€äº›æ ·æœ¬æœ‰ï¼Œä¸€äº›æ ·æœ¬æ²¡æœ‰ã€‚
    Reinforcement learning å¼ºåŒ–å­¦ä¹  ã€‚machine takes an action; teacher provides rewards

    • control

    • pricing

    • games

    Semi-supervised / active learning
    Evaluation words
    Representation: how to encode the raw data?
    Generalization: how well can we do on unseen data?
    Interpretation: how to explain the findings?
    Complexity: how much time and space?
    Efficiency: how many samples?
    Privacy: how to respect data privacy?
    Robustness: how to degrade gracefully under (malicious) error?

    Big data is a collection of data sets so large and complex that it becomes difficult to process using on- hand database management tools or traditional data processing applications.

    Characteristics of Big Data: 4V
    Volume
    Velocity
    Variaty
    Veracity

    AssumptionÂ¶

    ç‹¬ç«‹åŒåˆ†å¸ƒ independent & identically :math:`(i.i.d.) ` ã€‚å‡è®¾æ ·æœ¬ç©ºé—´ä¸­å…¨ä½“æ ·æœ¬æœä»ä¸€ä¸ªæœªçŸ¥ â€œåˆ†å¸ƒ distributionâ€ DDD ï¼Œç°æœ‰çš„æ¯ä¸ª sample éƒ½æ˜¯ç‹¬ç«‹åœ°ä»è¿™ä¸ªåˆ†å¸ƒä¸Šé‡‡æ ·å¾—åˆ°çš„ã€‚

    å…³äºåˆ†ç±»
    æœ‰å¾ˆå¤šçš„åˆ†ç±»æ¨¡å‹ï¼Œä»–ä»¬å„è‡ªæœ‰å„è‡ªçš„ä½œç”¨åŸç†ï¼Œä¹Ÿæœ‰å„è‡ªçš„å‡ ä½•è¡¨ç¤ºã€‚ä½†å½’æ ¹å…¶æœ¬è´¨è¿˜æ˜¯estimate distribution.

    identifiability of model æ¨¡å‹çš„å¯è¯†åˆ«æ€§Â¶

    Statistical Modelling and Identifiability of Parameters

    å‚æ•°çš„ å¯è¯†åˆ«æ€§ identifiability ä½¿æˆ‘ä»¬èƒ½å¤Ÿè·å¾—è¯¥å‚æ•°å€¼çš„ç²¾ç¡®ä¼°è®¡å€¼ã€‚åœ¨æ²¡æœ‰å¯è¯†åˆ«æ€§çš„æƒ…å†µä¸‹ï¼Œå³ä½¿æœ‰æ— é™æ¬¡è§‚æµ‹ï¼Œæˆ‘ä»¬ä¹Ÿæ— æ³•ä¼°è®¡å‚æ•°Î¸çš„çœŸå®å€¼ã€‚

    Xï½N(a+b, Ïƒ) is not identifiable
    Xï½N(Î¼, Ïƒ) is identifiable
    æ¯ä¸ªä¸åŒçš„ Î¼ éƒ½æŒ‡å‘ä¸€ä¸ªä¸åŒçš„æœŸæœ›ï¼ŒæŒ‡å‘ä¸åŒçš„æ­£æ€åˆ†å¸ƒï¼ŒåŒæ ·åœ°æ¯ä¸€ä¸ªæ‹¥æœ‰ä¸åŒæœŸæœ›çš„æ­£æ€åˆ†å¸ƒéƒ½èƒ½å”¯ä¸€æ±‚å‡ºä¸€ä¸ª Î¼ã€‚ä½†æ˜¯å¯¹ä¸åŒçš„ a å’Œ b æ¥è¯´ï¼Œa+b ä¹Ÿè®¸æ˜¯ç›¸åŒçš„ï¼Œæ„å‘³ç€ä¸€ä¸ªæ­£æ€åˆ†å¸ƒå¹¶ä¸èƒ½å”¯ä¸€æ¨æ–­å‡º (a, b, Ïƒ)çš„å€¼ã€‚ï¼ˆe.g. (1, 1, Ïƒ) = (0, 2, Ïƒ)

    DNNÂ¶

    why it is difficult for neural networks to be deep before 2010s.

    1. No enough computation resources,

    2. No enough training data,

    3. Gradient vanish problem and no advanced optimization techniques

    conditionÂ¶

    Product Rule, Chain Rule and Bayesâ€™ Rule?

    Product Rule: P(y)P(x|y)=P(x,y)
    Chain Rule: P(A1A2A3â€¦An)= P(A1|A2A3â€¦An) P(A2|A3A4â€¦An)â€¦ P(An-1| An) P(An)
    Bayesâ€™ Rule: P(Fâˆ£E)=P(Eâˆ£F)P(F)P(Eâˆ£F)P(F)+P(Eâˆ£Â¬F)P(Â¬F)P(F|E)=\cfrac{P(E|F)P(F)}{P(E|F)P(F)+ P(E|\neg F)P(\neg F)}P(Fâˆ£E)=P(Eâˆ£F)P(F)+P(Eâˆ£Â¬F)P(Â¬F)P(Eâˆ£F)P(F)â€‹
    â“Suppose 1 in 1000 persons has a certain disease. We have two test methods:
    1ï¸âƒ£ detect the disease (produce positive results) in 99% of the diseased persons and in 5% of the healthy persons (false alarm).
    2ï¸âƒ£ : detect the disease (produce positive results) in 90% of the diseased persons and in 1% of the healthy persons (false alarm). Which test method is better? Give the reason.
    ğŸ’¡ D:={Diseased person}; H={Healthy Persons}, +I ={Persons with positive results with Test method I}, +II ={Persons with positive results with Test method II }
    P(D)=0.001,P(+Iâˆ£D)=0.99,P(+Iâˆ£H)=0.05,P(+IIâˆ£D)=0.90,P(+IIâˆ£H)=0.01P(D)=0.001,\\ P(+I|D)=0.99, P(+I|H)=0.05,\\ P(+II|D)=0.90, P(+II|H)=0.01P(D)=0.001,P(+Iâˆ£D)=0.99,P(+Iâˆ£H)=0.05,P(+IIâˆ£D)=0.90,P(+IIâˆ£H)=0.01
    We compute the probability of a diseased person that can be detect by Test method I or Test method II, repectively, which is|
    P(Dâˆ£+I)=P(+Iâˆ£D)P(D)P(+Iâˆ£D)P(D)+P(+Iâˆ£H)P(H)=0.99Ã—0.0010.99Ã—0.001+0.05Ã—0.999=0.0194P(D|+I)= \cfrac{P(+I|D)P(D)}{P(+I|D) P(D)+ P(+I|H) P(H)}=\frac{0.99\times 0.001}{0.99\times0.001+0.05\times0.999}=0.0194P(Dâˆ£+I)=P(+Iâˆ£D)P(D)+P(+Iâˆ£H)P(H)P(+Iâˆ£D)P(D)â€‹=0.99Ã—0.001+0.05Ã—0.9990.99Ã—0.001â€‹=0.0194
    P(Dâˆ£+II)=P(+IIâˆ£D)P(D)P(+IIâˆ£D)P(D)+P(+IIâˆ£H)P(H)=0.90Ã—0.0010.90Ã—0.001+0.01Ã—0.999=0.0826P(D|+II)= \cfrac{P(+II|D)P(D)}{P(+II|D) P(D)+ P(+II|H) P(H)}=\frac{0.90\times 0.001}{0.90\times0.001+0.01\times0.999}=0.0826P(Dâˆ£+II)=P(+IIâˆ£D)P(D)+P(+IIâˆ£H)P(H)P(+IIâˆ£D)P(D)â€‹=0.90Ã—0.001+0.01Ã—0.9990.90Ã—0.001â€‹=0.0826
    P(Dâˆ£+I)<P(Dâˆ£+II)P(D|+ I)< P(D|+ II)P(Dâˆ£+I)<P(Dâˆ£+II) It means if a person has the disease, it has more chance of being detected by Test Method II. So Test method II is better.

    searchÂ¶

    A search algorithm is admissible if it is guaranteed to find a minimal path to a solution whenever such a path exists.

    Q4. the motivations of employing heuristics in solving AI problems?

    1. A problem may not have an exact solution because of ambiguities in problem statement or available data

    2. A problem may have an exact solution, but the computational cost (time and space) of finding it may be prohibitive.

    informed search methodâ€

    Hill-climbing search; A* algorithm; Best-first.

    Best-first searchÂ¶

    Best-first search is neither complete nor optimal âœ…

    step

    open

    closed

    notes

    1

    [S70]

    [ ]

    S=0+70

    2

    [A80, B85]

    [S70]

    A=45+35 < B=55+30

    3

    [B85, C100]

    [A80, S70]

    B85 < B_A=45+30+30 B85 < C= 45+25+30

    4

    [G100, C100]

    [B85, A85, S70]

    G=55+45 =C100

    5

    []

    [G100, C100, B85, A85, S70]

    Goal reached. Stop.

    Solution path : S-B-G

    Best-first â‡’âˆ€n,h(n)â‰¤hâˆ—(n)\xRightarrow{\forall n, h(n)\leq h^*(n)}âˆ€n,h(n)â‰¤hâˆ—(n)â€‹ A *algorithm

    Algorithm A* is a special best-first search algorithm âœ”ï¸

    All h(n)<=h*(n),so it is an A* algorithm and it is admissible. The path S-B-G is the shortest path.

    BNN, Bayesian Belief networkdÂ¶

    A Bayesian Belief Net consists of a graph and some local conditional probabilities.

    notes

    Serial connection: P(AVB)=P(Bâˆ£V)P(Vâˆ£A)P(A)P(AVB)=P(B|V)P(V|A)P(A)P(AVB)=P(Bâˆ£V)P(Vâˆ£A)P(A)
    Diverging Connection: P(AVB)=P(Bâˆ£V)P(Aâˆ£V)P(V)P(AVB)=P(B|V)P(A|V)P(V)P(AVB)=P(Bâˆ£V)P(Aâˆ£V)P(V)
    Converging Connection: P(AVB)=P(Vâˆ£AB)P(A)P(B)P(AVB)=P(V|AB)P(A)P(B)P(AVB)=P(Vâˆ£AB)P(A)P(B)
    Modus Ponens rule a,aâ€…â€ŠâŸ¹â€…â€Šbb\cfrac{a,a\implies b}{b}ba,aâŸ¹bâ€‹
    P(ABC)=P(AB)P(C)=.6âˆ—.8âˆ—.7=.336P(ABC)=P(AB)P(C)=.6*.8*.7=.336P(ABC)=P(AB)P(C)=.6âˆ—.8âˆ—.7=.336
    P(A)=.6âˆ—.8+.4âˆ—.2=.56P(A)=.6*.8+.4*.2=.56P(A)=.6âˆ—.8+.4âˆ—.2=.56
    P(AC)=P(A)P(C)=.56âˆ—.7=.392P(AC)=P(A)P(C)=.56*.7=.392P(AC)=P(A)P(C)=.56âˆ—.7=.392
    P(Dâˆ£B)=P(Dâˆ£BC)P(C)+(PDâˆ£BÂ¬C)P(Â¬C)=.8âˆ—.7+.2âˆ—.3=.62P(D|B)=P(D|BC)P(C)+(PD|B\neg C)P(\neg C)=.8*.7+.2*.3=.62P(Dâˆ£B)=P(Dâˆ£BC)P(C)+(PDâˆ£BÂ¬C)P(Â¬C)=.8âˆ—.7+.2âˆ—.3=.62

    P(Bâˆ£D)=P(BD)P(D)=P(Dâˆ£B)P(B)P(Dâˆ£B)P(B)+P(Dâˆ£Â¬B)P(Â¬B)=.62âˆ—.8.62âˆ—.8+.1âˆ—.2=.9612P(B|D)=\cfrac{P(BD)}{P(D)}=\cfrac{P(D|B)P(B)}{P(D|B)P(B)+P(D|\neg B)P(\neg B)}=\cfrac{.62*.8}{.62*.8+.1*.2}=.9612P(Bâˆ£D)=P(D)P(BD)â€‹=P(Dâˆ£B)P(B)+P(Dâˆ£Â¬B)P(Â¬B)P(Dâˆ£B)P(B)â€‹=.62âˆ—.8+.1âˆ—.2.62âˆ—.8â€‹=.9612
    P(Bâˆ£Â¬D)=P(BÂ¬D)P(Â¬D)=P(Â¬Dâˆ£B)P(B)1âˆ’P(D)=(1âˆ’P(Dâˆ£B))P(B)1âˆ’P(D)=.6281P(B|\neg D)=\cfrac{P(B\neg D)}{P(\neg D)}=\cfrac{P(\neg D|B)P(B)}{1-P(D)}=\cfrac{(1-P(D|B))P(B)}{1-P(D)}=.6281P(Bâˆ£Â¬D)=P(Â¬D)P(BÂ¬D)â€‹=1âˆ’P(D)P(Â¬Dâˆ£B)P(B)â€‹=1âˆ’P(D)(1âˆ’P(Dâˆ£B))P(B)â€‹=.6281

    Breadth-firth searchÂ¶

    If the search space contains very deep branches without solution, breadth-first search will be a better choice than depth-first search. Tâ€

    æœç´¢ç©ºé—´åŒ…å«éå¸¸æ·±çš„åˆ†æ”¯ â‰ \neqî€ = ç›®æ ‡åœ¨å¾ˆæ·±çš„åˆ†æ”¯é‡Œã€‚
    contains very deep branches without solution è¿™ä¸ªæ·±çš„æ”¯æ˜¯æ²¡æœ‰è§£ï¼Œé‚£ä¹ˆè§£åœ¨æµ…å±‚çš„èŠ‚ç‚¹é‡Œ â€…â€ŠâŸ¹â€…â€Š\impliesâŸ¹ BFS better

    breadth-first search

    storage cost

    • branch factor bbb

    • storage cost sss bytes/node

    • search speed vvv nodes/second

    • goal depth ddd

    âˆ‘i=0dbiÃ—s\sum_{i=0}^db^i\times si=0âˆ‘dâ€‹biÃ—s

    notes

    â“ For a searching tree, assume that the branch factor is b=10, the storage cost is 1000 bytes/node and the searching speed is 10,000 nodes/second. With breadth-first search, what is the required storage space at depth 3?
    ğŸ’¡ At depth 3, the number of created nodes is 1+10+100+1000=111,1, and thus the storage space is 111,1ï‚´1000=11,11K bytes.

    time complxity

    • branch factor bbb

    • goal depth ddd

    bd+1b^{d+1} bd+1

    ç¦»æ•£Â¶

    Why in some cases we need to use First Order Logic (FOL) rather than Propositional Logic (PL)?â€

    1. Propositional logic (PL) is too â€œcoarseâ€ to easily describe properties of objects.

    2. First order logic (FOL) is to extend the expressiveness of PL.

    notes

    Forward chaining in first order logic is a data-driven algorithm.
    Backwards chaining in first order logic is a goal-driven algorithm.

    âˆ€\forallâˆ€ & âˆƒ\existsâˆƒ

    • âˆ€xâˆ€y=âˆ€yâˆ€x\forall x\forall y=\forall y\forall xâˆ€xâˆ€y=âˆ€yâˆ€x

    • âˆƒx,y=Â¬âˆ€xÂ¬y\exists x, y = \neg \forall x\neg yâˆƒx,y=Â¬âˆ€xÂ¬y

    • âˆƒxâˆ€yâ‰ âˆ€yâˆƒx\exists x\forall y\neq \forall y \exists xâˆƒxâˆ€yî€ =âˆ€yâˆƒx

    Satisfiable: A sentence is satisfiable if there is some interpretation for which it is true.
    Unsatisfiable: A sentence is unsatisfiable if there is no interpretation for which it is true.
    Valid: A sentence is valid if it is true for every interpretation.

    Grid SearchÂ¶

    1. specify a list of possible hyperparameter values éœ€è¦äººä¸ºè®¾å®šè¶…å‚æ•°çš„èŒƒå›´

    2. Grid Search will train models with every possible combination of the provided hyperparameter values and assess the performance of each trained model using a specified metric (e.g., the accuracy of predictions on a test data set).     Loop: 1. Random guess 2. Check and compare 3. Update.

    1. provide statistical distributions of hyperparameter values äººä¸ºè®¾å®šè¶…å‚æ•°çš„åˆ†å¸ƒ
